intro: Galium orientale var. hirtum, commonly known as hairy bedstraw, is a flowering plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is a perennial herb characterized by its slender, ascending stems and opposite, ovate leaves that are covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers in clusters, typically blooming from late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its hairy stems and leaves distinguish it from other varieties within the Galium genus.
